Graphical abstract A catalyst consisting of palladium – nickel supported on exfoliated graphene oxide (PdNi/EGO) composite was synthesized. The catalytic activity was tested for ethanol oxidation reaction (EOR) in half-cell using cyclic voltammetry (CV) and subsequently it was used as an anode material in a direct ethanol fuel cell (DEFC). Transmission Electron Microscopy showed the catalyst particles are uniformly dispersed on the surface of graphene oxide with the particle size ranging from 3 to 6nm. X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy analysis of catalysts revealed that the surface consisting of mostly Pd, PdO, Ni(OH)2, and NiOOH. CV and chronoamperometry measurements demonstrated higher electrocatalytic activity and stability for PdNi/EGO in the alkaline medium than the unsupported PdNi and carbon black-supported PdNi (PdNi/C) catalysts. A single cell anion exchange membrane DEFC constructed with a PdNi/EGO anode catalyst showed a maximum power density of 16.6mWcm−2 at 50°C, which is higher than the unsupported PdNi, PdNi/C, and commercial Pd/C catalyst. Keywords PdNi Graphene oxide Ethanol oxidation reaction Electrocatalysis Direct ethanol fuel cell Anode catalyst 1 Introduction Direct ethanol fuel cell (DEFC) is widely recognized as one of the alternatives and clean energy devices. The use of ethanol as a fuel is greatly preferred because of its advantages such as high availability, low cost, easy handling, storage and transport management, and fewer hazard concerns. Generally, it is a promising fuel due to its high bioavailability, low toxicity and high energy density (6.8kWhL−1) [1]. In this regard, electrocatalysts with high catalytic activities toward the ethanol oxidation reaction (EOR) are needed to maximize the fuel cell performance. Recently, several studies focused on the development of electrocatalysts for direct ethanol fuel cell applications [2–4]. Platinum (Pt) is usually used as an anode catalyst for fuel cells due to its high catalytic activity with a wide range of fuels [5]. However, its use is limited by its high cost, low availability and prevalent poisoning by adsorbed intermediate compounds of ethanol. Thus, numerous studies have highlighted the reduction [5–8] or replacement [9–11] of Pt catalysts. Palladium (Pd) based catalysts are extensively studied as an alternative to Pt-based catalysts in alcohol oxidation due to its higher availability, lower cost and higher electrocatalytic activity towards the EOR in alkaline condition [4,10,12–14]. For instance, Ma and colleagues [15] have reported that Pd/C catalyst exhibited a higher ethanol oxidation activity than Pt/C in an alkaline condition which could be attributed to the inherent ability of Pd to cleave the CC bond needed for the effective oxidation of ethanol. Furthermore, Pd/C has higher poisoning tolerance and stability than Pt/C at low temperatures [15]. With the recent advancement in the alkaline membrane, studies on the application of Pd-based composites in alkaline conditions have increased [16]. Likewise, the addition of metal oxides such as NiO [17,18], CeO2 [18], SnO2 [19], and Co3O4 [20] on carbon black support has been reported to improve the activity of Pd towards EOR due to the bi-functional mechanism. Aside from reducing the Pd loading, it is presumed that the oxophilicity of these metals provide the necessary OH group needed for the oxidation of the surface-adsorbed ethanol molecules. Specifically, Pd catalyst with nickel oxide promoter has been investigated to obtain higher electrocatalytic activity towards ethanol oxidation than the other metal oxides (Co3O4, CeO2 and Mn3O4) [18]. To further increase the utilization of such catalysts, metal nanoparticles are usually dispersed on high surface area support materials. Carbon-based materials, such as carbon black, and carbon nanotubes are widely used supports [21]. Graphene, a two-dimensional carbon allotrope, is a promising carbon support due to its larger surface area compared to the other carbon materials [22–26]. Pt-based catalysts deposited on graphene nanosheets have been described to exhibit higher catalytic activity towards methanol oxidation than carbon black-supported Pt [26–30]. Graphene-supported Pd-based catalysts exhibited higher electrocatalytic activity towards the ethanol oxidation compared to carbon black-supported Pd catalysts [23–25]. Ghosh et al. have reported that the Pd catalyst exhibited an improved electrocatalytic activity towards ethanol oxidation upon the addition of graphene as a support material [31]. Furthermore, PdSn/graphene composite catalyst synthesized by Awasthi et al. [32] showed higher electrocatalytic activity towards the methanol oxidation in comparison to the Pd/graphene composite catalyst. An improvement in the activity towards the oxidation of ethanol was also observed with graphene-supported bimetallic PdSn, PdRu, and PdIr in comparison with monometallic Pd on graphene support [33]. Another study showed that when PdNi nanoparticles were supported on rGO, the catalyst composite exhibited an enhanced activity towards oxidation of formic acid [34]. Meanwhile, a preliminary study reported by our group on the use of electrochemically exfoliated graphene oxide from carbon rod as a support for PdNi revealed a higher electrocatalytic activity towards the ethanol oxidation reaction [35]. The source and quality of graphene are necessary to achieve higher electrocatalytic activities. In this article, we report the detailed electrochemical and physico-chemical characterizations of PdNi catalyst supported on exfoliated graphene oxide (PdNi/EGO) and compare the electrochemical performance with the unsupported PdNi and PdNi/C composites. To the best of our knowledge, so far, the fuel cell performance of the synthesized PdNi/EGO as an anode catalyst in alkaline direct ethanol fuel cell has not been reported. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of PdNi/EGO composites Graphite powder, purchased from Showa Chemical Co. Ltd. (Japan), was used as received. Palladium chloride (PdCl2), nickel chloride (NiCl2) and sodium borohydride (NaBH4) were of analytical grade and were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, Singapore. All solutions were prepared using Millipore system (Milli-Q SP-TOC; ≥18.2MΩcm−1) and sonicated to achieve homogeneity. Graphene oxide was fabricated from natural graphite flakes using a modified Hummer’s method [36]. The graphite oxide was exfoliated through ultrasonication. The dispersed exfoliated graphene oxide was separated from the unexfoliated graphite by centrifugation at 5000rpm for 20min and was dehydrated by lyophilization. In a typical synthesis, 60mg of exfoliated graphene oxide (EGO) was dispersed in 50mL ultrapure water by sonication for 30min before the addition of equal volumes (22.1mL) of 0.01M PdCl2 solution and 0.01M NiCl2 solution. The pH of the mixture was adjusted to pH 10 using 0.1M NaOH solution. Excess NaBH4 aqueous solution with a concentration of 2.0mgmL−1 was added slowly and stirred for 12h at room temperature. This mixture was filtered and washed repeatedly with ultrapure water. The resulting solid was wetted with a small amount of water and dried by lyophilization [26]. The same procedure was used to fabricate both PdNi/C and PdNi without carbon black. The metal loading of the carbon-supported PdNi and Pd:Ni atomic ratio was confirmed using thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX), respectively (Table 1 ). Both PdNi/EGO and PdNi/C gave 36.4 and 42.0% metal loading, respectively. On the other hand, the Pd to Ni ratios of the catalyst composites, i.e. PdNi, PdNi/C and PdNi/EGO, were 1:0.8, 1:0.97 and 1:0.96, respectively. Both PdNi/C and PdNi/EGO metal loading and Pd:Ni ratio were almost equal to the nominal values which are 40% PdNi and 1:1 Pd:Ni, respectively. 2.2 Characterization The powder X-ray diffraction patterns were obtained using a MiniFlex X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku, Japan) using a Cu Kα radiation (λ=0.15406nm). The 2θ angle ranges from 10° to 90° and was scanned at a rate of 0.5°min−1. The surface elemental analysis was performed using ESCALAB 250 XPS system (Thermo Fisher, Theta Probe System, USA), with a monochromatic Al Kα radiation at 150W, in the pass energy (PE) mode (PE=20eV). All of the spectra were obtained under identical conditions. Surface topography and morphology of EGO were investigated with NX-10 atomic force microscopy system (Park System, South Korea). The morphology and particle size of PdNi nanoparticles on different carbon supports were studied using HF-3300 transmission electron microscope system (Hitachi, Japan) at 200kV. Electrochemical measurements were conducted using a three electrode cell connected to a potentiostat (EDaQ, Australia). Pt wire, saturated silver/silver chloride (ALS Inc., Japan) and glassy carbon electrode (GCE, ALS Inc., Japan, ID: 3mm, 0.0707cm2) were used as a counter, reference, and working electrode, respectively. Catalyst powder with a mass of 5mg was dispersed in 4μL of 60% PTFE and 496μL of N,N-dimethylformamide solution and sonicated until homogenized. A small volume (∼2.9μL) of the ink was drop-casted onto the surface of the glassy carbon electrode with a loading of 100μgPd cm−2. For cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements, the working electrode was immersed in 1.0M ethanol in 0.1M NaOH solution saturated with high purity nitrogen (99.999%, Linde. Co, Philippines) with a potential window between −0.9V and 0.4V versus Ag/AgCl. 2.3 Membrane electrode assembly and fuel cell testing The catalyst performance was evaluated using a single fuel cell assembly. The selected catalysts were incorporated in the membrane electrode assembly (MEA) as an anode catalyst along with a commercially available Pt/C (40% Pt, Premetek, U.S.A.) as the cathode catalyst. The catalyst layers were prepared by coating the gas diffusion layer with the dispersion of the catalyst. Briefly, the catalyst ink was prepared by adding a few drops of deionized water to sufficient amount of the catalyst for a loading of 1mgPd cm−2. Then, 100mg of the ionomer, AS4 (Tokuyama, Japan), and 2mL of isopropyl alcohol was added to the catalyst and sonicated for 40min or more until it was homogeneous. The resulting catalyst ink was repeatedly hand-brushed onto a 5.0cm2 gas diffusion layer (Anode: Nickel Foam and Cathode: GDL 25 BC, SGL Carbon Ltd., Germany) until a uniform catalyst surface was achieved. This was done for both anode and cathode catalysts to produce the corresponding catalyst layers. The MEA was prepared by thermal pressing the anode and cathode catalyst layer to the PTFE re-enforced Tokuyama AHA membrane (Eurodia, France) in a sandwich fashion. The thermally pressed MEA was fixed in a cell fixture (Fuel Cell Technologies, USA). This cell fixture was attached to the fuel cell test station (SciTech, South Korea) for the polarization experiments. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphological, structural and surface characteristics of PdNi/EGO composites Exfoliation of graphite was confirmed by AFM and TEM as shown in Fig. 1 . The graphene oxide deposited on mica showed a typical sheet-like morphology (Fig. 1a), with a lateral dimension ranging from 100nm to 1.0μm. A representative sheet (Fig. 1a, magnified image) was measured to have a thickness of 0.7nm as shown in the line profile analysis in Fig. 1b. This measured thickness may be the indicative of two to few-layered graphene sheets with some consideration to the spacing between the graphene and substrate used [37]. In addition, a typical semi-translucent morphology was seen in the TEM image of EGO (Fig. 1c). This was observed with some wrinkles and folds, characteristics of few-layer graphene [38,39]. Catalyst impregnation and reduction of EGO were done with a typical chemical reduction with sodium borohydride without further addition of stabilizers and ligands. This was done to reduce the possible irreversible passivation of the catalyst due to the interaction with ligands [40] which may affect its electrochemical activity. The metal particles deposited on EGO exhibit sphere-like shape with particle size ranging from 2.5 to 6nm (mean=5.2nm), which was evaluated from an ensemble of 50 particles randomly selected from the TEM image (Fig. 2 a). Homogenously dispersed metallic particles supported on EGO are also evident from the TEM image. The average particle size of PdNi catalyst supported on graphene obtained from this work is relatively smaller compared to PdNixB catalyst supported on graphene synthesized by Krishna et al. [38] with an average particle size of 8–12nm. Deposition of Pd and Ni on EGO was confirmed by EDX spectra (Fig. 2b). Bulk structural information for PdNi, PdNi/C, and PdNi/EGO electrocatalyst composites was obtained by XRD as presented in Fig. 3 . All XRD data confirmed the presence of Pd and Ni(OH)2 particles. For PdNi catalysts with carbon-based support, the broad peak at around 2θ value of about 25° can be assigned to graphite (002) facet. This diffraction peak is prominent in the case of PdNi supported on carbon black indicating the presence of high amount of graphitic lattice in this carbon support. On the other hand, a small broad peak at around 22° is present in PdNi/EGO which corresponds to the remaining graphitic lattice, C (002). For both PdNi/C and PdNi/EGO catalysts, the four peaks around 2θ values of 40.36°, 45.68°, 68.40°, and 81.90° are assigned to the (111), (200), (220), and (311) facets of the face-centered cubic (fcc) crystalline Pd, respectively [41]. On the other hand, the small peaks at 2θ values of about 34.26° and 60.0° can be attributed to Ni(OH)2 (100) and (110) facets, respectively [42]. In addition, the absence of well-defined peaks for Ni metallic species indicates that amorphous Ni(OH)2 predominates the formed Ni species for all the catalysts. Based on Bragg’s and Scherrer’s equations [42]: (1) Particle Height, Z (nm)=0.89λCu-Kα/Bcos(2θ) (2) Lattice Height, d (nm)=λCu-Kα/2sin(2θ) where Z is the particle height, λCu-Kα is the wavelength of the X-ray source, B is the full width at half maximum (FWHM) and d is the lattice height of the particle. The lattice height of C (002) from EGO was calculated at 0.34nm with an average number of four graphene layers. Based on the broadening of the (220) diffraction peaks, the average size of the Pd particles was estimated to be 2.6nm in PdNi, 3.2nm in PdNi/C and 3.0nm in PdNi/EGO. The particle size estimated from XRD (mean=2.9nm) was smaller than the one obtained from TEM data (mean=5.2nm). The surface composition of PdNi/EGO was further confirmed using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) as shown in Fig. 4 . The XPS wide scan spectrum confirmed the presence of Pd (3d) and Ni (2p) along with O (1s) and C (1s). However, only Pd 3d and Ni 2p core level spectra were presented to emphasize and understand the surface chemistry of the catalyst system. Figs. 4a and b show the deconvoluted Ni 2p spectra and Pd 3d spectra of PdNi/EGO, respectively. The spin-orbit coupling was found in nickel-based systems, with the peak around 870eV–885eV attributed to Ni 2p1/2 [43]. The peak found from 845 to 869eV is due to the more intense Ni 2p3/2 signal and will be the focus of this article. The peaks located at 861 and 880eV are shake-up peaks arising from multi-electron excitation [44]. Deconvolution of the Ni 2p3/2 peaks revealed that the nickel species present are in the oxidized states: one at ∼855eV from Ni(OH)2 and another at 857eV from NiOOH [43]. The signal at 852eV, corresponding to metallic Ni, is surprisingly absent from the XPS spectra. The high relative percentages of nickel forms existing as Ni(OH)2 and NiOOH may stem from the possibility that surface-bound nickel atoms are prone to react with atmospheric O2 and H2O to form the oxide species. Quantitative calculations show that there is a lack of metallic nickel species available in the synthesized composites compared to nickel hydroxides and oxyhydroxides. This may be due to the oxophilic nature of Ni which could spontaneously convert Ni to its oxides. The dominance of Ni(OH)2 and NiOOH in this study is similar to the results of Shen and co-workers [17], and it is unclear at this point whether pure metallic nickel exists on the surface of the composites. Fig. 4b shows the characteristic major spin-orbit doublet for palladium system, with the binding energy peak located at 335 and 341eV correlated to Pd 3d5/2 and Pd 3d3/2, respectively, and also ascribed to metallic Pd [45]. The other doublet located at 337 and 342eV are contributions from the adsorbed oxygen-Pd interaction (PdOads) and PdO species, while palladium in a +4 oxidation state (as PdO2) was also identified by the last doublet at 338 and 343eV [46]. The formation of an evident shoulder at higher binding energies was due to the spontaneous oxidation of Pd by low oxygen base pressures [47]. Both Pd oxide species can be also attributed to the adsorbed H2O that was not completely removed during drying since it was lyophilized. Thus, annealing can be done in further studies to further decrease the formation of oxides from residual and adsorbed oxygenated compounds. 3.2 Electrochemical performance of PdNiO catalyst composites The electrochemical behavior of PdNi/EGO was studied using cyclic voltammetry (CV). As a comparison, PdNi unsupported and supported with carbon black was also evaluated. The characteristic electrochemical behavior of PdNi/EGO, PdNi/C, and PdNi modified electrodes in 0.5M NaOH obtained in the potential range of −0.90V to 0.40V for 5 cycles was presented in Fig. 5 . The CV curves are related to the hydroxide (OH−) adsorption/desorption on the active Pd surface of the electrode or composites. The positive-going potential sweep entails two processes which include the adsorption of hydrogen and oxidation of Pd to PdO. The hydrogen adsorption occurs at around −0.8V to −0.4V while it is still unclear which potential range Pd oxidizes to PdO in alkaline conditions [48]. However, it was suggested that PdO formation occurs at more positive potentials [48]. Moreover, the regeneration of Pd surface through the reduction of PdO to Pd occurs at around −0.2V to − 0.6V [48]. This cathodic peak can be used to estimate the electrochemically active surface area (EASA) of Pd catalysts. The catalytic activity of an electrocatalyst is known to depend on its electrochemically active surface area (EASA). To compute the EASA of the prepared catalysts, the equation EASA= Q/SI was used, where Q is the coulombic charge for the palladium oxide reduction, S is the proportionality constant (405μCcm−2) to correlate the charge with area and I is the catalyst loading [49]. The catalyst loading, or the amount of Pd, used in all of the catalysts was kept at 2.0μg. Using the said equation, PdNi/EGO exhibited the largest active Pd surface area of 335.4m2 g−1 Pd. Likewise, based on the respective CV from Fig. 5, unsupported PdNi and PdNi/C have exhibited electrochemically active surface area of 167.0m2 g−1 Pd and 244.4m2 g−1 Pd, respectively. This remarkable electrochemically active surface area value for PdNi/EGO could be attributed from the even dispersion of the catalyst nanoparticles on the large surface area of graphene [38,50] as evidenced by the TEM image in Fig. 2a. The catalytic behavior of PdNi composites towards EOR using 1.0M ethanol in 0.1M NaOH was evaluated using the two prominent curves in the cyclic voltammogram (Fig. 6 ). The first peak in the potential range of −0.2V to 0.0V for the positive-going scan is attributed to the primary oxidation of ethanol mainly as acetate [48]. The second peak in the range of −0.2V to −0.4V for the negative-going scan is attributed to the oxidative desorption of the unoxidized products mainly as acetate ions [48]. As presented in Table 2 , the electrocatalytic behavior of PdNi/EGO (770.6mAmg−1 Pd) towards oxidation of ethanol has significantly improved as compared to PdNi/C (604.6mAmg−1 Pd) and PdNi (250.5mAmg−1 Pd). In terms of current density, PdNi/EGO catalyst produced 19.8mAcm−2 which is almost similar to the work of Krishna and co-workers which obtained a current density of 19.7mAcm−2 for PdNixB/RGO [38]. Further oxidative desorption of the by-products, mainly acetate ions, occurs during the reduction of PdO and Pd-COads to Pd as described by the negative-going scan peak [48]. It is worthy of note that the remarkable enhancement of the catalytic activity of PdNi/EGO towards EOR was due to the larger active surface area of the catalysts on graphene support as seen in Fig. 5. This result demonstrates that graphene support is effective as it favors easy electron transport and charge transfer accessibility [38] and avoids agglomeration of nanoparticles, as evidenced by the TEM image in Fig. 2a. These results corroborate with the higher Jf/Jb ratio of PdNi/EGO than PdNi/C (Table 2), where Jf and Jb are the peak currents at forward and backward scan, respectively. This results in a higher tolerance to CO poisoning which is apparent with alcohol oxidation [32]. This may be attributed to the large presence of the oxygenated functional groups in the exfoliated graphene oxide which could serve as nucleation sites for the metal particles during the synthesis. In effect, a better dispersion of metal particles could occur causing larger exposed active surface area and possibly better interaction with the two metal particles. It is also believed that this is caused by the improvement in the interaction of Pd and Ni(OH)2 due to the greater dispersion and effective support-catalyst interaction of the catalyst [42]. For the kinetic studies, the Tafel plots of the synthesized catalysts (Fig. 7 ) were compared and evaluated. Based on Table 2, the PdNi/EGO catalyst had the lowest Tafel slope of 366mAdec−1. This indicates that PdNi/EGO catalyst has the fastest charge-transfer kinetics among all of the synthesized catalysts which could result to faster transport of electron and other active species from the EOR [51]. Chronoamperometry (CA) was used to investigate the effect of the support relative to the activity and stability of the catalyst towards ethanol oxidation. For the CA analysis, a constant potential of 0.1V was applied for 3000s at the working electrode immersed in 1.0M ethanol in 0.1M NaOH solution. As seen in Fig. 8 , all curves start with a high exchange current due to the initial oxidation of the ethanol. However, current decay can be observed during the first few seconds of the analysis due to the adsorption of CO-like species on the Pd catalysts which cause poisoning of the catalysts [31]. It can be seen that the limiting current of the PdNi/EGO is higher compared to the other synthesized catalysts during the entire period indicating a better stability of the PdNi/EGO. The PdNi/EGO catalyst composite retained 44.0% of its maximum current produced which is higher than the carbon-supported PdNi (40.0% retention) and unsupported PdNi (13.0% retention). The EGO sheets could assist in the effective dispersion of the PdNi nanoparticles, facilitating an easier access of ethanol molecules to the catalytic sites [31]. 3.3 Direct ethanol fuel cell performance of PdNiO/EGO anode catalysts The polarization and power density curves of DEFCs using the fabricated PdNi composites as the anode catalyst are presented in Fig. 9 . The measurements were made by feeding 1.0M ethanol mixed with 1M NaOH at 2mLmin−1 and 100sccm of oxygen to the fuel cell at a temperature of 50°C. The DEFC performance of the fabricated MEA with different anode catalyst composites was evaluated using both their open-circuit voltage (OCV) and power density. In the case of unsupported PdNi, it displayed an OCV of 0.84V with a maximum power density of 5.0mWcm−2 at an operating voltage of 0.098V. PdNi/C showed an OCV of 0.84V with a maximum power density of 12.5mWcm−2 at an operating voltage of 0.25V. Meanwhile, PdNi/EGO exhibited an OCV of 0.89V and a maximum power density of 16.6mWcm−2 at an operating voltage of 0.23V. The PdNi/EGO composite revealed the highest OCV and power density compared to the other catalyst composites. In addition, PdNi/EGO exhibited a higher power density as compared to the commercially available Pd/C catalyst (8.8mWcm−2) as shown in Fig. S1 (Supporting Information). 4 Conclusions We have shown the possibility of utilizing graphene-based materials, particularly graphene oxide, as support material for PdNi composite synthesized using borohydride reduction. TEM studies of the synthesized PdNi/EGO revealed a uniform distribution of PdNi nanoparticles with an average particle size of 5.2nm. XPS studies showed that the catalyst particles exist as Pd, PdO, Ni(OH)2, and NiOOH. The PdNi/EGO catalyst exhibited a greater catalytic activity and stability towards ethanol oxidation reaction in the alkaline medium compared to PdNi/C and PdNi. This enhancement of electrocatalytic activity can be attributed to the higher electrochemically active surface area demonstrated by graphene-supported PdNi. The PdNi/EGO catalyst gave the highest OCV and power density as compared with the other PdNi composites and commercially available Pd/C catalyst. Based on these electrochemical and fuel cell characteristics, PdNi/EGO is a promising anode material for direct ethanol fuel cell application. coredata.dc:description: A catalyst consisting of palladium – nickel supported on exfoliated graphene oxide (PdNi/EGO) composite was synthesized. The catalytic activity was tested for ethanol oxidation reaction (EOR) in half-cell using cyclic voltammetry (CV) and subsequently it was used as an anode material in a direct ethanol fuel cell (DEFC). Transmission Electron Microscopy showed the catalyst particles are uniformly dispersed on the surface of graphene oxide with the particle size ranging from 3 to 6nm. X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy analysis of catalysts revealed that the surface consisting of mostly Pd, PdO, Ni(OH)2, and NiOOH. CV and chronoamperometry measurements demonstrated higher electrocatalytic activity and stability for PdNi/EGO in the alkaline medium than the unsupported PdNi and carbon black-supported PdNi (PdNi/C) catalysts. A single cell anion exchange membrane DEFC constructed with a PdNi/EGO anode catalyst showed a maximum power density of 16.6mWcm−2 at 50°C, which is higher than the unsupported PdNi, PdNi/C, and commercial Pd/C catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Preparation and characterization of palladium-nickel on graphene oxide support as anode catalyst for alkaline direct ethanol fuel cell
